bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 16, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas recommends King as superintendent of Yellowstone Park. He discusses the functions and administration of the Sanitary Department.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 16, 1905
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
CANAL ZONE.
Ancon, C. Z., August 16, 1905a.
Major, Jefferson R. Kean,
Surgeon-General's Office, U. S. Army,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Captain King, of the Cavalry, has just left us permanently.
He wishes to get the titleposition of Superintendent of Yellow Stone Park, and
asks me to write you for your good offices in the matter, as far as
Ainsworth is concerned.

Captain King is an excellent Officer, active, energetic, and
could be safely recommended from any point of view. He expects to
see you himself on the subject and will let you know just what he wants.

In our Department, I think things are doing pretty well down
here. The health of the Command remains excellent and yellow fever
is decreasing, - have had only seven cases during August. I am looking
forward to getting all of our mennon-memsl out of Colon and Panama, and put them
in tentage somewhere along the line. The Commission are making efforts
to get their employees out and as soon as they do so, I will arrange to
get the non-immune civilian population out. These will amount to some
five hundred persons. If tentage is decided upon for this pur-
pose, could I get four or five of your field hospitals? I ask because
I know you have them in stock and I could get them quickly.

Phillips, Straub and KendallSchermer are working hard and going at it
with zest. Phillips, being used to our free and easy army ways, is in-
-- 2 --
clined to rebel, though, at what he thinks undue red tape. I think
I heard him swearing a little the other day, when he was informed from
this office that he had to make out ten copies of every requisition,
but he calmed down when I explained to him how we had been educated
in an irresponsible school, where no method was observed, and it really
was necessary at his time of life, that he learn the proper property
accountability, and that to begin on ten requisitions was absolutely
necessary for this proper accountability.

Mrs. Gorgas and I continue well, and expect to start early
in September for the States, for the purpose of putting Aileen to
school.
Please give my kindest regards to General O'Rielly.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas.
Chief Sanitary Officer. W.
